segment.source: A calendar view lets a user view and interact with a calendar that they can navigate by month, year, or decade.
segment.target: A calendar view lets a user view and interact with a calendar that they can navigate by month, year, or decade.

segment.source: Calendar view
segment.target: Calendar view

segment.source: Calendar view
segment.target: Calendar view

segment.source: A calendar view lets a user view and interact with a calendar that they can navigate by month, year, or decade.
segment.target: A calendar view lets a user view and interact with a calendar that they can navigate by month, year, or decade.

segment.source: A user can select a single date or a range of dates.
segment.target: A user can select a single date or a range of dates.

segment.source: It doesn't have a picker surface and the calendar is always visible.
segment.target: It doesn't have a picker surface and the calendar is always visible.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: CalendarView class
segment.target: CalendarView class

segment.source: Date property
segment.target: Date property

segment.source: Is this the right control?
segment.target: Is this the right control?

segment.source: Use a calendar view to let a user pick a single date or a range of dates from an always visible calendar.
segment.target: Use a calendar view to let a user pick a single date or a range of dates from an always visible calendar.

segment.source: If you need to let a user select multiple dates at one time, you must use a calendar view.
segment.target: If you need to let a user select multiple dates at one time, you must use a calendar view.

segment.source: If you need to let a user pick only a single date and don’t need a calendar to be always visible, consider using a calendar date picker or date picker control.
segment.target: If you need to let a user pick only a single date and don’t need a calendar to be always visible, consider using a calendar date picker or date picker control.

segment.source: For more info about choosing the right control, see the Date and time controls article.
segment.target: For more info about choosing the right control, see the Date and time controls article.

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: The calendar view is made up of 3 separate views: the month view, year view, and decade view.
segment.target: The calendar view is made up of 3 separate views: the month view, year view, and decade view.

segment.source: By default, it starts with the month view open.
segment.target: By default, it starts with the month view open.

segment.source: You can specify a startup view by setting the DisplayMode property.
segment.target: You can specify a startup view by setting the DisplayMode property.

segment.source: The 3 views of a calendar view
segment.target: The 3 views of a calendar view

segment.source: Users click the header in the month view to open the year view, and click the header in the year view to open the decade view.
segment.target: Users click the header in the month view to open the year view, and click the header in the year view to open the decade view.

segment.source: Users pick a year in the decade view to return to the year view, and pick a month in the year view to return to the month view.
segment.target: Users pick a year in the decade view to return to the year view, and pick a month in the year view to return to the month view.

segment.source: The two arrows to the side of the header navigate forward or backward by month, by year, or by decade.
segment.target: The two arrows to the side of the header navigate forward or backward by month, by year, or by decade.

segment.source: Create a calendar view
segment.target: Create a calendar view

segment.source: This example shows how to create a simple calendar view.
segment.target: This example shows how to create a simple calendar view.

segment.source: The resulting calendar view looks like this:
segment.target: The resulting calendar view looks like this:

segment.source: Example of calendar view
segment.target: Example of calendar view

segment.source: Selecting dates
segment.target: Selecting dates

segment.source: By default, the SelectionMode property is set to Single.
segment.target: By default, the SelectionMode property is set to Single.

segment.source: This lets a user pick a single date in the calendar.
segment.target: This lets a user pick a single date in the calendar.

segment.source: Set SelectionMode to None to disable date selection.
segment.target: Set SelectionMode to None to disable date selection.

segment.source: Set SelectionMode to Multiple to let a user select multiple dates.
segment.target: Set SelectionMode to Multiple to let a user select multiple dates.

segment.source: You can select multiple dates programmatically by adding DateTimeDateTimeOffset objects to the SelectedDates collection, as shown here:
segment.target: You can select multiple dates programmatically by adding DateTimeDateTimeOffset objects to the SelectedDates collection, as shown here:

segment.source: A user can deselect a selected date by clicking or tapping it in the calendar grid.
segment.target: A user can deselect a selected date by clicking or tapping it in the calendar grid.

segment.source: You can handle the SelectedDatesChanged event to be notified when the SelectedDates collection has changed.
segment.target: You can handle the SelectedDatesChanged event to be notified when the SelectedDates collection has changed.

segment.source: NoteFor important info about date values, see DateTime and Calendar values in the Date and time controls article.
segment.target: NoteFor important info about date values, see DateTime and Calendar values in the Date and time controls article.

segment.source: Customizing the calendar view's appearance
segment.target: Customizing the calendar view's appearance

segment.source: The calendar view is composed of both XAML elements defined in the ControlTemplate and visual elements rendered directly by the control.
segment.target: The calendar view is composed of both XAML elements defined in the ControlTemplate and visual elements rendered directly by the control.

segment.source: The XAML elements defined in the control template include the border that encloses the control, the header, previous and next buttons, and DayOfWeek elements.
segment.target: The XAML elements defined in the control template include the border that encloses the control, the header, previous and next buttons, and DayOfWeek elements.

segment.source: You can style and re-template these elements like any XAML control.
segment.target: You can style and re-template these elements like any XAML control.

segment.source: The calendar grid is composed of CalendarViewDayItem objects.
segment.target: The calendar grid is composed of CalendarViewDayItem objects.

segment.source: You can’t style or re-template these elements, but various properties are provided to let you to customize their appearance.
segment.target: You can’t style or re-template these elements, but various properties are provided to let you to customize their appearance.

segment.source: This diagram shows the elements that make up the month view of the calendar.
segment.target: This diagram shows the elements that make up the month view of the calendar.

segment.source: For more info, see the Remarks on the CalendarViewDayItem class.
segment.target: For more info, see the Remarks on the CalendarViewDayItem class.

segment.source: The elements of a calendar month view
segment.target: The elements of a calendar month view

segment.source: This table lists the properties you can change to modify the appearance of calendar elements.
segment.target: This table lists the properties you can change to modify the appearance of calendar elements.

segment.target: IsTodayHighlighted, TodayFontWeight, TodayForeground

segment.source: By default, the month view shows 6 weeks at a time.
segment.target: By default, the month view shows 6 weeks at a time.

segment.source: You can change the number of weeks shown by setting the NumberOfWeeksInView property.
segment.target: You can change the number of weeks shown by setting the NumberOfWeeksInView property.

segment.source: The minimum number of weeks to show is 2; the maximum is 8.
segment.target: The minimum number of weeks to show is 2; the maximum is 8.

segment.source: By default, the year and decade views show in a 4x4 grid.
segment.target: By default, the year and decade views show in a 4x4 grid.

segment.source: To change the number of rows or columns, call SetYearDecadeDisplayDimensions with the your desired number of rows and columns.
segment.target: To change the number of rows or columns, call SetYearDecadeDisplayDimensions with the your desired number of rows and columns.

segment.source: This will change the grid for both the year and decade views.
segment.target: This will change the grid for both the year and decade views.

segment.source: Here, the year and decade views are set to show in a 3x4 grid.
segment.target: Here, the year and decade views are set to show in a 3x4 grid.

segment.source: By default, the minimum date shown in the calendar view is 100 years prior to the current date, and the maximum date shown is 100 years past the current date.
segment.target: By default, the minimum date shown in the calendar view is 100 years prior to the current date, and the maximum date shown is 100 years past the current date.

segment.source: You can change the minimum and maximum dates that the calendar shows by setting the MinDate and MaxDate properties.
segment.target: You can change the minimum and maximum dates that the calendar shows by setting the MinDate and MaxDate properties.

segment.source: Updating calendar day items
segment.target: Updating calendar day items

segment.source: Each day in the calendar is represented by a CalendarViewDayItem object.
segment.target: Each day in the calendar is represented by a CalendarViewDayItem object.

segment.source: To access an individual day item and use its properties and methods, handle the CalendarViewDayItemChanging event and use the Item property of the event args to access the CalendarViewDayItem.
segment.target: To access an individual day item and use its properties and methods, handle the CalendarViewDayItemChanging event and use the Item property of the event args to access the CalendarViewDayItem.

segment.source: You can make a day not selectable in the calendar view by setting its CalendarViewDayItem.IsBlackout property to true.
segment.target: You can make a day not selectable in the calendar view by setting its CalendarViewDayItem.IsBlackout property to true.

segment.source: You can show contextual information about the density of events in a day by calling the CalendarViewDayItem.SetDensityColors method.
segment.target: You can show contextual information about the density of events in a day by calling the CalendarViewDayItem.SetDensityColors method.

segment.source: You can show from 0 to 10 density bars for each day, and set the color of each bar.
segment.target: You can show from 0 to 10 density bars for each day, and set the color of each bar.

segment.source: Here are some day items in a calendar.
segment.target: Here are some day items in a calendar.

segment.source: Days 1 and 2 are blacked out.
segment.target: Days 1 and 2 are blacked out.

segment.source: Days 2, 3, and 4 have various density bars set.
segment.target: Days 2, 3, and 4 have various density bars set.

segment.source: Calendar days with density bars
segment.target: Calendar days with density bars

segment.source: Phased rendering
segment.target: Phased rendering

segment.source: A calendar view can contain a large number of CalendarViewDayItem objects.
segment.target: A calendar view can contain a large number of CalendarViewDayItem objects.

segment.source: To keep the UI responsive and enable smooth navigation through the calendar, calendar view supports phased rendering.
segment.target: To keep the UI responsive and enable smooth navigation through the calendar, calendar view supports phased rendering.

segment.source: This lets you break up processing of a day item into phases.
segment.target: This lets you break up processing of a day item into phases.

segment.source: If a day is moved out of view before all the phases are complete, no more time is used trying to process and render that item.
segment.target: If a day is moved out of view before all the phases are complete, no more time is used trying to process and render that item.

segment.source: This example shows phased rendering of a calendar view for scheduling appointments.
segment.target: This example shows phased rendering of a calendar view for scheduling appointments.

segment.source: In phase 0, the default day item is rendered.
segment.target: In phase 0, the default day item is rendered.

segment.source: In phase 1, you blackout dates that can't be booked.
segment.target: In phase 1, you blackout dates that can't be booked.

segment.source: This includes past dates, Sundays, and dates that are already fully booked.
segment.target: This includes past dates, Sundays, and dates that are already fully booked.

segment.source: In phase 2, you check each appointment that's booked for the day.
segment.target: In phase 2, you check each appointment that's booked for the day.

segment.source: You show a green density bar for each confirmed appointment and a blue density bar for each tentative appointment.
segment.target: You show a green density bar for each confirmed appointment and a blue density bar for each tentative appointment.

segment.source: The class in this example is from a fictitious appointment booking app, and is not shown.
segment.target: The class in this example is from a fictitious appointment booking app, and is not shown.

segment.source: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.
segment.target: \[This article contains information that is specific to Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps and Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
segment.target: For Windows 8.1 guidance, please download the Windows 8.1 guidelines PDF.\]
